   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days leading to this
   rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated
   - f/u sputum culture final results, currently yeast
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean from ventilator today given continued fluid overload
   and hypotension requiring pressors, will reassess once HD able to take
   off fluid
   - will obtain blood cultures today for surveillance, consider
   antifungal if blood cultures indicate yeast as is seen in current
   sputum cultures.
   - Cont daily trial of pressure support at 15/10.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Is on midodrine at HD for hypotension
   as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal decrease in
   required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses prn, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - HD today, will plan for likely zero UF.
   - continue check central venous sat, yesterday [**3-2**] was 70, to help
   determine if hypovolemia/cardiogenic vs. sepsis as cause of hypotension
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen much more tender
   this morning, no recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - d/c lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
 their input appreciated
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan to assess UOP status in setting of unclear
   interpretation of elevated bladder pressures
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   - seriel abd pressures, last bladder pressure 22 and 24, unable to
   interpret given body habitus, fluid overload.
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for CVVH today once new IR guided HD line placed
   - d/c midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue HD for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; currently on fent/versed due to
   increase in abd tenderness
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today [**3-3**] is day 12 of antibiotics. Per report, appears to be
   improving.  Not producing BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl to complete at least a 14 day course
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed.  Will place insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, will add insulin to TPN
   - Meds via OGT
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR,
   lansoprazole
   .
   # Access: R CVL placed [**2-20**].  Plan for pt to go to IR today for change
   of R CVL with L HD CVL for continued HD.
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of Candida in the sputum culture, C. difficile colitis, and peritonitis. Sepsis can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver failure, and cardiovascular instability.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia and lung injury. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging due to the patient's underlying lung disease and fluid overload.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a combination of factors, including sepsis, hypovolemia, and medication-induced vasodilation. Continued use of vasopressors and fluid boluses may be necessary to maintain blood pressure.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's oliguric acute renal failure is likely due to a combination of prerenal azotemia, ATN, and HRS. CVVH may be necessary to manage the patient's fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be due to HIT, which requires prompt treatment to prevent bleeding complications.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium is likely multifactorial, including uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, and severe infection. Continued use of broad-spectrum antibiotics and HD may be necessary to manage the patient's delirium.
7. Hematochezia: The patient's hematochezia has resolved, but continued monitoring of stool output and serial abdominal exams is necessary to detect any potential recurrence.
8. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile colitis is likely due to the presence of Candida in the sputum culture. Continued treatment with PO and PR vancomycin may be necessary to complete the 14-day course.
9. Air near tail of pancreas: The patient's air near the tail of the pancreas may be due to a microperforation or pancreatico-colonic fistula. Continued monitoring of the patient's abdominal exam and imaging studies may be necessary to detect any potential complications.
10. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely due to a combination of nutritional and liver disease-related factors. Continued use of vitamin K and FFP may be necessary to manage the patient's coagulopathy.

Based on the patient's complex medical condition and the potential complications listed above, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of the patient's condition in the ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 125 kg male admitted to the ICU with a complex medical history, including type II diabetes, hypertension, and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, hepatitis, and renal failure. He is currently receiving CVVH, and his blood pressure has been dropping to the 70s. Levo has been titrated up to 0.22 to maintain a stable blood pressure. Insulin has been increased in his TPN, and oral feeds have been discontinued due to absorption concerns.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, and blood pressure of 114/65 mmHg. His respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 50%. His lab results show elevated WBC count, decreased platelet count, and abnormal liver enzymes.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding risk: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is receiving anticoagulation therapy, which increases his risk of bleeding.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreased, which may increase his risk of bleeding.
3. Hepatitis: The patient has a history of hepatitis, which may increase his risk of liver failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a history of acute renal failure, which may worsen his condition if not managed properly.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving respiratory support, but his respiratory status may deteriorate if not managed properly.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of Clostridium difficile infection, which may increase his risk of sepsis and organ failure.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's TPN may not be providing adequate nutrition, which may lead to malnutrition and worsening of his condition.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust his platelet transfusions as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management and dialysis as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his respiratory support as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's infection status and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.
7. Consider adjusting the patient's TPN to provide adequate nutrition.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated on pressure support
   - f/u cultures
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for some net removal of fluid.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options, including initiating feeds today
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 20, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and multiple comorbidities, including chronic liver disease, hepatitis B and C, and diabetes mellitus type 2. He has a history of aspiration, ileus, and possible small bowel obstruction. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is dropping, and he requires levophed to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 65 mmHg. He has had asymptomatic hypotension in the past, and his blood pressure may not tolerate further fluid removal.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 109 K/uL, which is low. He has a positive HIT antibody, and his platelet count is dropping. This may be a false positive due to hemodialysis, and a serotonin assay is pending.
3. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: The patient has a combination of ATN and prerenal azotemia, and he is receiving hemodialysis. His creatinine level is 4.0 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 123 mg/dL.
4. Delirium: The patient is unable to assess his mental status due to sedation, but he has been experiencing delirium on the floor. This may be multifactorial, including uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, and severe infection.
5. C. diff. Colitis: The patient has a severe case of C. diff. colitis, and he has received 14 days of antibiotics. He is still not producing bowel movements, and he may require IVIG if his next stool sample is still positive.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.3, which is likely due to nutritional and liver disease. He has received multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he does not wean off the ventilator or if he develops pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's hypotension and low blood pressure may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest.
3. Infection: The patient's severe infection may lead to sepsis or septic shock if not properly treated.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's ileus and possible small bowel obstruction may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel perforation or abscesses.
5. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause confusion, disorientation, and altered mental status.
6. Renal Failure: The patient's oliguric acute renal failure may worsen if he does not receive proper treatment, leading to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is unstable, and he requires close monitoring and treatment of his multiple comorbidities. He should continue to receive mechanical ventilation, hemodialysis, and broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat his infection. He should also receive treatment for his C. diff. colitis, coagulopathy, and delirium. His family should be informed of his condition and treatment plan, and they should be involved in decision-making regarding his care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues. The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.2°F)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 114/65 mmHg (with a range of 78/45 mmHg to 125/75 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient has a history of:

* Thrombocytopenia, heparin-induced (HIT, HITT)
* Abdominal pain, including abdominal tenderness
* Ascites
* C. difficile infection (C diff, CDiff colitis, Clostridium difficile)
* Diabetes mellitus, type II
* Gastrointestinal bleed, lower (hematochezia, BRBPR, GI bleed, GIB)
* Hepatitis other
* Hypertension, benign
* Hypotension (not shock)
* Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)

The patient is currently receiving:

* Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH)
* Levo (titrated up to 0.22 at 5 pm)
* Insulin in total parenteral nutrition (TPN), discontinued Glargine SC
* Fentanyl and midazolam infusions
* Norepinephrine infusion
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) and other ICU medications

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
* Increased risk of infection due to C. difficile infection and compromised immune system
* Worsening of renal failure and potential need for dialysis
* Respiratory failure and potential need for mechanical ventilation
* Gastrointestinal bleed and potential need for endoscopy or surgery
* Hypotension and potential need for vasopressor therapy
* Increased risk of sepsis and organ dysfunction due to compromised immune system

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and implement appropriate interventions to prevent or manage them.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated, trial of pressure support
   - f/u culture final results
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean from ventilator today given continued fluid overload
   and hypotension requiring pressors, will reassess once CVVH able to
   take off fluid
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for likely zero UF.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
 their input appreciated
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 18, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; currently on fent/versed due to
   increase in abd tenderness
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-4**]) is day 13 of antibiotics. Per report, appears to
   be improving.  Not producing BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl to complete at least a 14 day course
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed.  Will increase insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via OGT
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR,
   lansoprazole
   .
   # Access: L CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R HD
   for CVVH
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

   and hypotension requiring pressors, will reassess once CVVH able to
   take off fluid
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for likely zero UF.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
 their input appreciated
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 18, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; currently on fent/versed due to
   increase in abd tenderness
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-4**]) is day 13 of antibiotics. Per report, appears to
   be improving.  Not producing BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl to complete at least a 14 day course
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed.  Will increase insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via OGT
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR,
   lansoprazole
   .
   # Access: L CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R HD
   for CVVH
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and sepsis. He has a complex medical history, including chronic liver disease, hepatitis B and C, and chronic pancreatitis. He is currently intubated and ventilated, with a diagnosis of hypoxic respiratory failure and aspiration pneumonia. He has also developed oliguric acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy. He is receiving CVVH and has been treated with antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further escalation of his ventilator settings or consideration of tracheostomy.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's AKI is likely to progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) if not managed properly.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be related to his liver disease, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding and require further management.
6. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause confusion, disorientation, and even coma.
7. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status, and require further management.
8. Gastrointestinal (GI) Complications: The patient's GI status is complex, and he may develop further complications such as ileus, obstruction, or perforation.
9. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing further infections, particularly respiratory and urinary tract infections.
10. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, and he may develop further complications such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals, and consider further escalation of therapy if necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's AKI with CVVH and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's coagulopathy with FFP and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatitis and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's GI status and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and consider further evaluation and treatment if necessary.

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his management plan as necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 125 kg male admitted to the ICU with a complex medical history. The patient has a history of abdominal pain, thrombocytopenia, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). He also has a history of ascites, Clostridioides difficile infection, type II diabetes, gastrointestinal bleed, and hypertension.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 36.7°C
* Heart rate: 103 bpm
* Blood pressure: 88/53 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 549 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 28 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 12 cmH2O. He is also receiving infusions of fentanyl, norepinephrine, and midazolam.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 109 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 18.8 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 123 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.8 g/dL
* LDH: 327 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continuing to manage his respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation
* Monitoring for and treating any signs of sepsis
* Managing his thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions
* Continuing to provide nutrition through total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Monitoring his blood glucose levels and adjusting his insulin therapy as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Sepsis and multi-organ failure
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding complications
* Renal failure and acute kidney injury
* Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation
* Hypertensive emergencies and cardiac complications
* Hyperglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status. The patient's treatment plan should be adjusted as needed to address any new complications or changes in his condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 125 kg individual with a complex medical history, including type II diabetes, hypertension, and a history of gastrointestinal bleed, hepatitis, and renal failure. The patient is currently in the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and thrombocytopenia.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98.1°F)
* Heart rate: 103 bpm (92-112 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 88/53 mmHg (64-112/80 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (15-35 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 100%
* CVP: 12 mmHg (6-15 mmHg)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 109 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 28 mg/dL
* Glucose: 123 mg/dL
* Albumin: 1.8 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.0 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.9 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* A CT scan of the abdomen reveals ascites and a distended stomach.
* An echocardiogram shows normal cardiac function.

The patient's physical examination is significant for:

* Sclera icteric
* Poor dentition
* Obvious tenderness to palpation diffusely
* 1+ RLE edema
* Trace LLE edema

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl: 200 mcg/hour
* Norepinephrine: 0.2 mcg/Kg/min
* Midazolam (Versed): 5 mg/hour
* Pantoprazole (Protonix): 40 mg every 8 hours
* TPN with lipids: 77 mL/hour

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued CVVH for renal support
* Heparin-free therapy to prevent further bleeding
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding and platelet transfusion as needed
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure and adjusting ventilation settings as needed
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting antibiotics as needed
* Monitoring for signs of liver dysfunction and adjusting medications as needed

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
* Respiratory failure due to underlying lung disease or sepsis
* Renal failure due to acute kidney injury or sepsis
* Sepsis due to underlying infections or colonization
* Liver dysfunction due to underlying liver disease or sepsis
* Pancreatitis due to underlying pancreatitis or sepsis
* Cardiac arrest due to underlying cardiac disease or sepsis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to underlying gastrointestinal disease or sepsis
* Diabetic ketoacidosis due to underlying diabetes and inadequate insulin therapy.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated.  Appears acutely
   worse this AM in regards to his increasing pressor requirement as well
   as his worsening ABG on PS.
   - Given worsening overall hemodynamic status, will turn patient back
   onto rate.  No vent wean for now.
   - f/u cultures, [**2-29**] sputum with yeast
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   - will discuss with ID regarding recommendations for possible addition
   of antifungal given previous sputum culture with yeast and development
   of worsening hemodynamics.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with steady
   increase in pressor requirement to attain required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - will add vasopressin at this point for second pressor
   - remains on CVVH
   - cont CVVH today, anticipate net even due to worsening hemodynamics.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with decreased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM, has not stooled in
   days.  Bladder pressure today 40.
   - will contact surgery regarding overall worsening status for
   recommendations regarding possibility of CT abd/pelvis and whether
   findings on CT a/p would change overall surgical plan.
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - will d/c PR vanco
   - F/u Surgery recs
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder pressure increasing
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-6**]) is day 15 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
s.  Worsening abd exam today.
   - will d/c PR vanco today, cont PO vanco
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via IV
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR, PPI
   .
   # Access: L-CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R-HD
   line for CVVH
   .
   # Code: DNR per recent discussion with HCP son [**Name (NI) 5420**] on [**3-5**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated.  Appears acutely
   worse this AM in regards to his increasing pressor requirement as well
   as his worsening ABG on PS.
   - Given worsening overall hemodynamic status, will turn patient back
   onto rate.  No vent wean for now.
   - f/u cultures, [**2-29**] sputum with yeast
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   - will discuss with ID regarding recommendations for possible addition
   of antifungal given previous sputum culture with yeast and development
   of worsening hemodynamics.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with steady
   increase in pressor requirement to attain required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - will add vasopressin at this point for second pressor
   - remains on CVVH
   - cont CVVH today, anticipate net even due to worsening hemodynamics.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with decreased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM, has not stooled in
   days.  Bladder pressure today 40.
   - will contact surgery regarding overall worsening status for
   recommendations regarding possibility of CT abd/pelvis and whether
   findings on CT a/p would change overall surgical plan.
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - will d/c PR vanco
   - F/u Surgery recs
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder pressure increasing
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-6**]) is day 15 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
s.  Worsening abd exam today.
   - will d/c PR vanco today, cont PO vanco
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via IV
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR, PPI
   .
   # Access: L-CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R-HD
   line for CVVH
   .
   # Code: DNR per recent discussion with HCP son [**Name (NI) 5420**] on [**3-5**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now
   ICU Care

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a complex medical condition, including:

1. Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF) with hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to aspiration, ileus, and possible SBO.
2. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure (ARF) with combination of ATN and prerenal azotemia, requiring CVVH.
3. Coagulopathy with INR 2.3, likely due to nutritional and liver disease components.
4. Thrombocytopenia with dropping platelets and positive HIT antibody, requiring avoidance of heparin products.
5. Delirium, likely multifactorial, including uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, and severe infection.
6. C. diff. colitis, requiring PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl, with worsening abdominal exam and no bowel movement.
7. Air near tail of pancreas, possibly due to microperf or pancreatico-colonic fistula.
8. Hematochezia, resolved with 3 units of PRBCs.
9. Hepatitis B and C, with HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL.
10. Diabetes Mellitus type 2, requiring insulin in TPN.

The patient's current condition is critical, with increasing pressor requirement, worsening hemodynamics, and oliguric ARF. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's abdominal exam is worsening, with no bowel movement, and there is concern for possible SBO or ileus.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure, including worsening ARF and possible need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis, including possible development of septic shock.
3. Multi-organ failure, including possible failure of kidneys, liver, and lungs.
4. Gastrointestinal complications, including possible SBO, ileus, or perforation.
5. Hemorrhagic complications, including possible bleeding from coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia.
6. Infection, including possible development of pneumonia, peritonitis, or sepsis.
7. Cardiovascular complications, including possible development of cardiogenic shock.

The patient's code status is DNR, and the family has been informed of this decision. The patient's son has requested that no specific information be given to other family members.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical history. They have been admitted with respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and thrombocytopenia. The patient's condition has been stable over the past 24 hours, with no significant changes in vital signs or laboratory results. They continue to require mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). The patient's abdominal pain has persisted, and they have a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, ascites, and Clostridium difficile infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and they continue to require mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of further deterioration, including the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's renal function has deteriorated, and they require CRRT. There is a risk of further kidney damage and the need for dialysis.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count remains low, and there is a risk of bleeding complications.
4. Abdominal Complications: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness may indicate ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding, ascites, or other complications.
5. Infection: The patient has a history of Clostridium difficile infection and may be at risk of developing further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate ongoing cardiovascular instability, and there is a risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
7. Metabolic Complications: The patient's glucose levels have been unstable, and there is a risk of further metabolic derangements, including hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

Overall, the patient's condition remains critically ill, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve their outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated on pressure support
   - f/u cultures
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for some net removal of fluid.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options, including initiating feeds today
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 20, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-5**]) is day 14 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl (now has had a 14 day course)
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via IV
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR, PPI
   .
   # Access: L-CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R-HD
   line for CVVH
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and multiple comorbidities. The patient has a history of Hepatitis B and C, alcoholism, and cirrhosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure, intubated and stable on ventilator, with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 12 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular: Hypotensive, requiring levophed to maintain a MAP > 65, with a systolic blood pressure of 88 mmHg and a diastolic blood pressure of 53 mmHg.
* Renal: Oliguric acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 3.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 96 mg/dL.
* Hematological: Thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 109 x 10^9/L, and a positive HIT antibody.
* Gastrointestinal: C. difficile colitis, with a stool culture positive for C. difficile, and a pending serotonin assay to rule out a false-positive HIT antibody.
* Neurological: Delirium, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10, and a pending electroencephalogram (EEG) to rule out seizures.
* Abdominal: Distended abdomen with increased bowel sounds, and a pending CT abdomen/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perforation.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Aspiration pneumonia
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Sepsis
* Thrombocytopenia
* C. difficile colitis
* Acute kidney injury
* Hypotension
* Delirium

The patient's laboratory results include:

* Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 18.8 x 10^9/L, Hct 28.0%, platelet count 109 x 10^9/L
* Blood chemistry: Creatinine 3.2 mg/dL, BUN 96 mg/dL, albumin 1.8 g/dL, LDH 327 IU/L, Ca++ 8.7 mg/dL, Mg++ 1.8 mg/dL, PO4 2.9 mg/dL
* Liver function tests (LFTs): AST 110 IU/L, ALT 18 IU/L, Alk Phos 230 IU/L, T Bili 0.8 mg/dL
* Coagulation studies: INR 2.3, PT 22.2 seconds, PTT 45.9 seconds

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue ventilation, weaning as tolerated on pressure support
* Treat for HAP/aspiration with vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole
* Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
* Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still for CVVH
* Continue to follow abdominal exam and consider repeat CT abdomen/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perforation
* Continue to hold octreotide which may be worsening ileus
* Avoid excessive narcotics
* Continue to follow lactate, trending downward
* Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option for medical management only

The patient's code status is full code.

   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated on pressure support
   - f/u cultures
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for some net removal of fluid.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs

   - follow lactate, trending downward

   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today

   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.

   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of

   - avoid heparin products for now

   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP

   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will

   - Continue to follow exam.
